text: Moments that stretch you or moments that you feel uncomfortable in or you find yourself saying, "Oh shit. I shouldn't be here," or, "I'm under qualified to be here," those are the moments you should be seeking out. Those are the moments that stretch you and give you a new foundation. So oftentimes you'll hear a career question like, "Hey, do you feel like you're growing in your role?" And that's a very ambiguous, in my opinion, way to ask this question.
speaker: Lane Shackleton
context: Lenny asks Lane about career growth and how to assess whether someone is developing professionally. Lane explains his concept of "oh shit moments" - situations where you feel unqualified or uncomfortable because you're being stretched beyond your current capabilities. He argues that these moments are actually indicators of growth and should be actively sought out, rather than the typical vague question about whether someone feels they're growing in their role.
text_ko: 자신을 시험에 들게 하거나 불편하게 만드는 순간들, 또는 "어휴, 내가 여기 있어도 되는 걸까?", "내가 여기 올 자격이 없나?"라고 느끼게 되는 순간들이 바로 찾아야 할 순간이에요. 그런 순간들이 당신을 한 단계 끌어올리고 새로운 토대를 마련해줘요. 그래서 흔히들 "지금 맡은 역할에서 성장하고 있다고 느껴요?"라고 묻는데, 제 생각엔 그 질문은 너무 애매해요.
text_zh: 那些让你感到压力的时刻，或者让你不舒服的时刻，或者你会想"我去，我不应该在这儿"，或者"我根本不够格在这儿"的时刻，这些才是你应该主动去寻找的时刻。正是这些时刻能够锻炼你，给你打下新的基础。所以你经常会听到有人问职业相关的问题，比如"嘿，你觉得你在这个岗位上有成长吗？"在我看来，这种问法太模糊了。
text_es: Los momentos que te sacan de tu zona de cómodo o cuando te sientes incómodo, o cuando te dices "Ay, no mames, no debería estar aquí" o "No estoy calificado para esto", esos son exactamente los momentos que deberías buscar. Esos son los momentos que te hacen crecer y te dan una nueva base. Entonces muchas veces escuchas preguntas de carrera como "Oye, ¿sientes que estás creciendo en tu puesto?" Y esa es una manera muy ambigua, en mi opinión, de hacer esa pregunta.

text: The core job of a product person in general is to turn ambiguity into clarity. And if you think about the job of a product leader or a product manager, everything is ambiguous all the time. It's like what's my role on this team? What problem are we solving? Who's the target customer? What prototype is going to solve this particular problem? So it's literally everything.
speaker: Lane Shackleton
context: Lenny asks Lane about the core principles he's identified for great product managers. Lane shares his unifying thesis that the fundamental job of any product person is to turn ambiguity into clarity. He explains that product managers constantly face unclear situations - from understanding their role to identifying problems and solutions - and their primary skill must be spotting ambiguity and making it clear.
text_ko: 프로덕트 담당자(product person)의 핵심 업무는 보통 애매한 걸 명확하게 만드는 거예요. 프로덕트 리더(product leader)나 프로덕트 매니저(product manager)의 역할을 생각해 보면, 모든 게 항상 불확실해요. 이 팀에서 내 역할이 뭔지? 우리가 해결하려는 문제는 뭔지? 타겟 고객은 누구인지? 어떤 프로토타입(prototype)이 이 문제를 해결할지? 이런 것들이니까요. 결국 말 그대로 모든 걸 다 다루는 거예요.
text_zh: 产品人员的核心工作就是把模糊不清的东西变得清晰明了。你想想产品负责人或者产品经理(product manager)的工作，什么都是模糊的——我在团队里到底是干什么的？我们要解决什么问题？目标用户是谁？什么样的原型(prototype)能解决这个具体问题？可以说是方方面面都不清楚。
text_es: El trabajo fundamental de alguien en producto es básicamente convertir lo que no está claro en algo que sí lo esté. Y si te pones a pensar en el rol de un líder de producto o un product manager, todo es ambiguo todo el tiempo. O sea, ¿cuál es mi papel en este equipo? ¿Qué problema estamos resolviendo? ¿Quién es nuestro cliente objetivo? ¿Qué prototipo va a resolver este problema específico? Literalmente es todo.

text: Goals with good intentions don't work. I really need to give a common example. A really common example is teams that are trying to learn about customers or do research. And one thing I've observed is a team may have a goal like an OKR of talking to 10 customers this quarter and they may or may not hit that OKR. And then if you watch closely, the next quarter, they may not have a goal of talking to customers anymore.
speaker: Lane Shackleton
context: Lenny asks about Lane's principle of "systems not goals." Lane explains this concept using Jerry Seinfeld's approach to comedy writing, where the system (writing for an hour every morning) matters more than the goal (building up material). He argues that teams often set well-intentioned goals like OKRs to talk to customers, but without a consistent system, these goals are inconsistently achieved and abandoned.
text_ko: 좋은 의도로 세운 목표는 잘 작동하지 않아요. 예를 들어볼게요. 고객에 대해 배우거나 연구를 하려는 팀이 흔한 예인데요. 제가 관찰한 바로는, 어떤 팀이 이번 분기에 고객 10명과 이야기하겠다는 OKR을 세우고, 그 목표를 달성할 수도 있고 못할 수도 있어요. 그런데 자세히 보면, 다음 분기에는 고객과 이야기하겠다는 목표가 아예 없어지는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 光有好想法的目标是没用的。我得举个特别常见的例子。最典型的就是那些想了解客户、做调研的团队。我发现很多团队会定个OKR目标，比如这个季度要跟10个客户聊聊，但他们不一定能完成这个OKR。然后你仔细观察就会发现，下个季度他们可能就不再把跟客户聊天当目标了。
text_es: Los objetivos con buenas intenciones no funcionan. Necesito dar un ejemplo muy común. Un ejemplo súper típico son los equipos que están tratando de conocer mejor a sus clientes o hacer investigación. Y algo que he visto es que un equipo puede tener un objetivo como un OKR de hablar con 10 clientes este trimestre y puede que lo logren o puede que no. Y si te fijas bien, el siguiente trimestre, es posible que ya ni tengan como meta hablar con clientes.

text: Instead of being obsessed with the goal, be obsessed with the system that gets you there. And so the phrase I sometimes use is goals with good intentions don't work. And to draw a contrast, that's just really different than a team that has some default on system for talking to customers. Every few times a week they're talking to customers for whatever reason.
speaker: Lane Shackleton
context: Lane continues explaining his "systems not goals" principle by contrasting teams that set customer research goals versus teams that have systematic approaches. He describes how at Coda they had a "default on" system where customers came in every Friday, forcing the team to always have something to show and creating consistent customer interaction rather than sporadic goal-driven research.
text_ko: 목표(goal)에 집착하기보다는 그 목표로 데려다 주는 시스템(system)에 집착하세요. 그래서 제가 가끔 하는 말이 “의도만 좋은 목표(goal)는 통하지 않아요.”라고 해요. 반대로 고객과 대화하는 기본적인 시스템(system)을 갖춘 팀은 완전히 달라요. 일주일에 몇 번씩이라도 특별한 이유가 없어도 꾸준히 고객과 대화하기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 别老盯着目标不放，应该专注于能带你达成目标的体系。我经常说的一句话就是：光有好想法的目标是没用的。形成对比的是，那些真正厉害的团队都有一套默认的客户沟通体系。他们每周都会定期跟客户聊几次，不管是什么原因。
text_es: En lugar de obsesionarte con la meta, obsesiónate with el sistema que te lleva ahí. Y por eso a veces digo que las metas con buenas intenciones no funcionan. Y para hacer un contraste, eso es muy diferente a un equipo que tiene por defecto un sistema para hablar con los clientes. Varias veces a la semana están hablando con clientes, por la razón que sea.

text: We basically have five levels and we call them role stages and they go from apprentice to principal. So apprentice is ... Rope analogy here is learns about rope. Practitioner is can tie basic knots, shown complex knots. Given a problem, they can do it. Career is you can calculate rope strength. You know a lot about knots. Principal is basically invented nylon.
speaker: Lane Shackleton
context: Lenny asks about how Coda structures their career levels and performance reviews. Lane explains their unique five-level system that applies across all roles (product, design, engineering) rather than having separate ladders for each function. He uses a rope analogy to illustrate the progression from apprentice (learning basics) to principal (fundamental innovation), emphasizing that the highest level should be aspirational with an exceptionally high bar.
text_ko: 우리는 기본적으로 다섯 단계가 있고, 이를 역할 단계(role stages)라고 부르며 견습(apprentice)부터 프린시펄(principal)까지 이어져요. 견습은 기본적으로 밧줄에 대해 배우는 단계예요. 실무자(practitioner)는 기본 매듭은 스스로 묶을 수 있고, 복잡한 매듭은 보여주면 따라 할 수 있어요. 문제를 주면 해결할 수 있어요. 커리어(career) 단계는 밧줄의 강도를 계산할 수 있고 매듭에 대해 아주 많이 아는 수준이에요. 프린시펄(principal)은 거의 나일론을 발명해낸 사람 같은 수준이에요.
text_zh: 我们基本上分五个级别，叫做角色阶段(role stages)，从学徒(apprentice)到首席专家(principal)。学徒就是...用绳子打个比方，就是刚开始了解绳子。从业者(practitioner)呢，能打基本的结，看懂复杂的结，给他个问题，他能解决。职业级(career)的话，你能算出绳子的强度，对各种结法都很懂。首席专家(principal)基本上就是发明尼龙的那种人。
text_es: Básicamente tenemos cinco niveles que llamamos etapas de rol (role stages) y van desde aprendiz hasta principal. Entonces, aprendiz es... usando la analogía de la cuerda, aprende sobre cuerdas. Practicante ya puede hacer nudos básicos, se le muestran nudos complejos. Si le das un problema, lo puede resolver. Carrera es que ya puedes calcular la resistencia de la cuerda. Sabes un montón sobre nudos. Principal básicamente es el que inventó el nylon.

text: The core insight here is that you want your teams to feel like they're building a cathedral and not laying bricks. And I think it's really, really easy to do when PMs are really busy on a day-to-day to just be one task after the other, really execution oriented and maybe not take the time to help the team take a broader frame, open the aperture a little bit and have a view of what the cathedral is.
speaker: Lane Shackleton
context: Lenny asks about Lane's "cathedrals, not bricks" principle. Lane shares the classic story of three people laying bricks - where one sees just moving bricks, another sees applying cement, but the third sees building a cathedral. He explains that product managers often get caught up in day-to-day execution without helping their teams understand the broader vision and purpose behind their work.
text_ko: 핵심은 팀이 단순히 벽돌을 쌓는 사람이 아니라 대성당을 짓고 있다는 느낌을 받게 하는 거예요. 그런데 일상적으로 프로덕트 매니저들(PMs)이 너무 바쁘면, 정말정말 한 작업이 끝나면 바로 다음 작업으로 넘어가는 식으로 실행 위주로만 일하게 되기 쉬고, 팀이 좀 더 큰 관점에서 보게끔 잠깐 시야를 넓혀 주거나 대성당이 어떤 모습인지 보여줄 시간을 못 내는 경우가 많아요.
text_zh: 这里的核心洞察就是，你要让团队觉得他们是在建造大教堂，而不是在搬砖。我觉得产品经理(PM)每天忙得不可开交的时候，特别容易陷入这种状态——就是一个任务接一个任务地做，特别注重执行，可能就没时间帮团队拉开视野，放宽格局，让大家看到我们到底在建什么样的大教堂。
text_es: La clave aquí es que quieres que tus equipos sientan que están construyendo una catedral y no simplemente poniendo ladrillos. Y creo que es súper fácil que pase cuando los PMs están muy metidos en el día a día, van de tarea en tarea, muy enfocados en la ejecución, y a lo mejor no se toman el tiempo para ayudar al equipo a ver el panorama más amplio, abrir un poco la perspectiva y tener una visión de qué es esa catedral que están construyendo.
